Electrochemical energy (e.g., fuel cell and metal-air batteries) is featured by large theoretical energy density, high conversion efficiency, safe operation and pollution-free emission. However, the sluggish dynamics of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and high cost of noble metals hinder their widespread commercial applications in electrochemical energy devices. Herein, we present a method for the preparation of the N, S co-doped carbon film wrapped Co nanoparticles (Co/NSC) for ORR by aging and then pyrolyzing the mixture of cobalt salt and 1-(p-Toluenesulfonyl)imidazole. The co-doping of N and S facilitates the electron rearrangement of the carbon film, resulting in a rapid electron transfer. The core-shell structure enhances the interaction between N, S co-doped carbon film and Co nanoparticles. These features endow the Co/NSC catalyst an excellent ORR with a half-wave potential of 0.860 V and limiting current density of 6.2 mA cm-2, besides the superior anti-methanol. The Co/NSC catalyst as the air cathode grants the assembled zinc-air battery high open circuit voltage (1.467 V), large peak power density (156.2 mW cm-2), great specific capacity (747.9 mAh gZn -1), and excellent stability. Thus, the prepared Co/NSC catalyst exhibits a promising application in zinc-air battery. This work provides an approach for the synthesis of the carbon-shell coated non-noble metal catalyst and its subsequent applications in oxygen electrocatalysis. Graphical abstract Simple method for the synthesis of Co@C for boosting the ORR Performance Image, graphical abstract Keywords Core-shell structure Oxygen reduction reaction Non-noble metal catalysts N, S co-doping Zinc-air battery Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Fuel cells and metal-air batteries are potential clean energy technologies to alleviate the energy crisis and environmental issues because of their advantages of high theoretical efficiency, environmental friendly, and safe operation [1–5]. However, the slow kinetic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in the air cathode of these devices results in a low energy conversion efficiency and, consequently, impedes their large-scale applications [6,7]. Pt or Pt-based alloys are commonly regarded as the best catalysts toward ORR due to their high energy conversion efficiency [8–11]. However, using these noble metals involves in high cost, low stability, and bad interferences to other fuels (e.g., methanol) and/or intermediates (e.g., COads), which greatly hinders their commercial application in oxygen electrocatalysis. Thus, it is urgent for the development of non-precious metal catalysts for ORR [12–14]. The non-precious metal catalysts towards ORR are featured by accessible active sites, low adsorption/desorption energy of ORR-related species, and accelerated kinetic process [15–17]. From the well-known ‘‘volcano plots’’ [18], Co located at the position near Ru, which endows it proper binding energy to bond oxygen and high activity for ORR. Moreover, Co is relatively abundant and cheap compared to other metals appeared in the ‘‘volcano plots’’. Thus, it is essential to perform the researches on the Co and/or Co-based materials for ORR. Previous reports demonstrated that the heteroatom (e.g., N, F, S, P and B) doped carbon composites supported transition metals exhibited excellent ORR performance [19–23]. For example, Sharma et al. synthesized a highly efficient ORR catalyst composed of N-doped graphene assembled cobalt-molybdenum nitrogen oxide (Co-Mo-ON/NG), in which the nitrogen atoms rearrange the electronic state of Co atoms and enhance the interaction of different elements, in addition to the synergistic effect between the dendritic nitrogen-doped graphene and the loaded metals nanoparticles [24]. Compared with single-atom doping, the multi-doping of carbon materials is more favorable because of the increasing asymmetric rotation and their enhanced charge regulation, thus promoting the adsorption and reduction of oxygen species [25,26]. At present, the preparation of multi-doped carbon composites loaded with transition metals composites requires a variety of heteroatomic precursors [27,28] or expensive carbon substances (e.g., graphene and carbon nanotube) [29–32]. Thus, it is necessary to simplify the heteroatomic precursors and decrease the cost to prepare non-noble metal catalysts. To overcome the above issues, here, we present a method for the preparation of N, S co-doped carbon film wrapped cobalt nanoparticles catalyst (Co/NSC) for ORR by the pyrolysis of the mixture containing 1-(p-Toluenesulfonyl)imidazole (C10H10N2O2S), cobalt salt (Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O), and zinc salt (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O), in which only 1-(p-Toluenesulfonyl)imidazole was selected as the precursor of the N, S co-doped carbon film, thus avoiding the use of a variety of heteroatomic precursors or expensive carbon substances and simplifying the preparation process. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and TEM mapping images indicated that the Co nanoparticles were coated with the N, S co-doped carbon film. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra demonstrated the active site of Co-N-C exists in the prepared Co/NSC catalyst. The electrochemical measurements showed that the Co/NSC catalyst possesses an excellent ORR performance and high peak power density (156.2 mW cm-2), large specific capacity (747.9 mAh gZn -1) for Zn-air batteries. This work provides a simple approach for the preparation of highly efficient ORR catalyst and its subsequent application in oxygen catalysis. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials Nafion (5 wt%) was bought from Sigma-Aldrich, methanol (CH3OH, analytical grade) was ordered from Shantou Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd., commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) was purchased from JM, potassium hydroxide (KOH, analytical grade), C10H10N2O2S (99%), cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, analytical grade), zinc(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, analytical grade), and zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(OAc)2·2H2O, analytical grade) were supplied by Aladdin. All chemicals that were purchased were used directly. 2.2 Synthesis of the cobalt-modified N and S co-doped carbon catalyst Initially, 75 mg of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 225 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 10 mL of CH3OH to form a solution A, and 672 mg of C10H10N2O2S were dissolved in 10 mL CH3OH containing 500 μL ammonia to develop a solution B, respectively. Thereafter, the obtained two solutions were ultrasonically mixed and aged for 10 h, after which the precipitates were obtained by washing, vacuum drying, and then labeled as Co-TSIM. Finally, the obtained Co-TSIM was pyrolyzed at 950 °C for 3 h in a tube furnace under N2 protection. The obtained sample was marked Co/NSC. 2.3 Physical characterizations The XRD pattern was obtained using X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD, D/MAX-2500 V/PC). The surface area and the pore size distribution were obtained using porosity analyzer (Quantachrome, NOVA 1200e). Scan electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7500F) and high-resolution TEM (JEM-2100) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, X-Max-65T) were used to obtain the compositions and morphology of the as-prepared samples. XPS (ESCALAB 250Xi) spectra were used to analyze the elemental compositions and states of the as-prepared samples. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Prior to the electrochemical measurements, the catalyst ink was prepared as follows: 3 mg of the as-prepared catalyst was added into 1 mL ethanol solution containing 25 μL of nafion and ultrasonicated into a homogenous ink. Then, 30 μL of the catalyst ink was coated on the as-polished RDE/RRDE (0.19625/0.247 cm2) to maintain the catalyst loading of 0.45 mg cm-2. The catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts toward ORR was measured on an electrochemical workstation (WaveDriver 200, Pine, USA) equipped with a three-electrode system, in which a saturated calomel electrode (SCE), glassy carbon disk/ring-disk electrode (RDE/RRDE), and graphite sheet, as the reference, working, and counter electrodes, respectively. The electrolyte was an O2- or N2- saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. All the applied potential was calibrated to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to the following formula: E ( R H E ) = E ( SCE ) + 0.241 + 0.0591 pH The electron transfer number (n) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) yield were calculated using the following formulas. n = 4 N · I D / ( N · I D + I R ) % H 2 O 2 = 200 · I R / ( N · I D + I R ) Where N represents the current collection efficiency (N = 0.37). I D and I R represent the disk and ring current, respectively. 2.5 Zn-air battery measurements A home-assembled Zn-air battery was used to evaluate the actual application of the as-prepared catalyst. The Zn-air battery was filled with 6.0 M KOH + 0.2 M Zn(OAc)2 electrolyte. The anode material was an as-polished zinc plate, and the air cathode was a carbon paper coated with Co/NSC or commercial Pt/C catalyst (1.0 mg cm-2). 3 Results and discussion The preparation of Co/NSC is schematically displayed in Fig. 1 a. Initially, the metal salts were reacted with 1-(p-Toluenesulfonyl)imidazole to produce a precipitated precursor. In the subsequent pyrolysis process, the obtained precursor was decomposed into Co/NSC, and the N, S co-doped carbon film was coated on the surface of Co nanoparticles. During the pyrolysis process, C10H10N2O2S provides the C-, N- and S-resources and converts into the N and S co-doped carbon film. The Zn cations were used to enlarge the surface areas by the evaporation of Zn atoms at high temperature. Furthermore, the successful fabrication of Co nanoparticles and homogeneous coating of carbon film could be validated through TEM image (Fig. 1b, c). The lattice fringes for the Co core and carbon shell are 0.206 and 0.341 nm, respectively (Fig. 1c) [33,34]. TEM-EDS mapping images (Fig. 1d-i) again validate the core-shell structure of Co/NSC, and their elemental compositions are S, C, N, O and Co. Characteristically, these results demonstrate the successful synthesis of Co/NSC. No lattice fringe and elemental signal for Zn are seen, which can be ascribed to the evaporation of Zn atoms at high temperature and is concordant with previous reports [35,36]. The XRD pattern of Co/NSC shows a broad signal peak of C (002) crystal plane at approximately 26.38° (JCPDS: PDF#41–1487), indicating that the precursor has been carbonized to graphitic carbon at 950 °C (Fig. 2 a). A comparison of the XRD patterns of the standard card (JCPDS: PDF#15–0806) and Co/NSC reveals that the three peaks at approximately 44.22°, 51.52° and 75.85° are credited to Co (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes, respectively (Fig. 2a) [37]. The evaporation of Zn and O atoms at high temperature can accelerate the formation of high specific surface area of carbon materials. To convince this viewpoint, the N2 sorption experiments demonstrates the pore size of Co/NSC samples, which is mainly distributed in the micropore range (0∼2 nm), in addition to little mesoporous (2∼6 nm) (Fig. 2b). The N2 sorption isotherms of Co/NSC samples exhibits the curves of IV isotherms (Fig. 2b, inset), which confirms that the micropore-mesoporous structure of Co/NSC samples and is consistent with the results of the distribution of pore size. The graded micropores and mesoporous in Co/NSC samples are conducive to the rapid transfer of oxygen species [38–40]. The specific surface area for Co/NSC is 339.6 m2 g-1, which is much greater than that of other N, S co-doped carbon materials reported previously (248 m2 g-1 [41], 178 m2 g-1 [42], 139.8 m2 g-1 [43]), and is supported by SEM images, where a rough surface is seen (Fig. S1a, b). Thus, the Co/NSC catalyst can offer highly exposed active sites for ORR. The chemical valences and compositions of the Co/NSC samples were analyzed by XPS. The full XPS survey of Co/NSC samples shows the signal peaks of S 2p, C 1 s, O 1 s, N 1 s and Co 2p at 164, 285, 401, 532 and 780 eV, and the atomic ratio of S, C, N, O, and Co is 0.72:87.31:4.97:5.51:1.49 (Fig. S2). The fitted peaks located at 284.62, 284.98, 285.97 and 288.51 eV are corresponded to C = C/CC, C = N/CO, C-S-C and OC = O, respectively [44,45] (Fig. 3 a). This result indicates the successful doping of N and S in the prepared Co/NSC. In addition, the hydrophilic oxygen-containing groups (CO and OC = O) in Co/NSC samples are beneficial to the adsorption of hydroxide groups (OH-) to promote the ORR process [15]. The N 1 s high-resolution spectrum exhibits four nitrogen species, including pyridinic N at 398.00 eV, Co-N at 398.98 eV, pyrrolic N at 401.05 eV, and graphitic N at 402.50 eV [46] (Fig. 3b). The S 2p high-resolution spectrum shows that the spin orbits energy of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of thiophen-S (C-S-C) are located at 164.00 and 165.16 eV, respectively, which is positively shifted 1 eV compared to the reported value [47] (Fig. 3c). This result confirms the electron rearrangement in Co/NSC. Moreover, the other peak at 168.02 eV is assigned to the satellite peak of S 2p [48]. The Co 2p high-resolution spectra displays that the Co0, Co2+, Co–NX, and satellite peaks are located at 778.85, 780.86, 782.99, and 786.79 eV, respectively [49] (Fig. 3d). This result indicates the active sites of Co–NX in Co/NSC [50–52]. To evaluate the ORR performance on Co/NSC, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurement was first performed in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. The half-wave potential (E 1/2) and limiting current density of the catalyst are shown in Fig. 4 a. The limiting current density is approximately 6 mA cm−2, suggesting a quick reaction rate of ORR on Co/NSC. The half-wave potential (E 1/2) is commonly used to assess the catalytic activity of a catalyst; specifically, a high E 1/2 represents an excellent catalytic activity of the material [53]. The E 1/2 of Co/NSC (0.860 V) is comparable to that of commercial Pt/C (0.865 V) and greater than of other reported non-noble metal catalysts listed in Table 1 [54–65]. A comparison of E 1/2 of Co/NSC and Co/NC [63] indicates that N and S co-doped carbon materials facilitate the ORR enhancement. The Tafel curves originated from the LSV polarization curves (Fig. 4a) are shown in Fig. 4b. A comparison of the Tafer slop of Co/NSC and commercial Pt/C discloses the similar kinetics for ORR. This result indicates that the Co/NSC possesses promising application in ORR [66,67]. The main reaction paths of ORR include four-electron (4e-) process to form water (H2O) and two-electron (2e-) process to yield hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The 4e- process is more efficient in energy conversion compared to 2e- process. The ORR path can be estimated by the electron transfer number (n) or H2O2 yield. The RRDE experiment measured the n and H2O2 yield according to the formulas mentioned in the experimental section. As shown in Fig. 4c and d, the n value of Co/NSC catalyst is 3.91∼3.97, inferring the major pathway in ORR involves 4e-. Moreover, the H2O2 yield maintains a low level (1.45∼4.43%) at the potential windows. The above results verify that the prepared Co/NSC can be considered a high-efficiency catalyst in electrochemical energy devices (e.g., metal-air batteries and fuel cells) [66,68]. The ORR on the catalyst is declined easily by the methanol interference originated from the cathode of the galvanic cells. Therefore, a study on the anti-methanol of catalyst is necessary. The methanol-tolerance experiment of the catalyst is conducted by chronoamperometry (CA). The current density of Co/NSC catalyst remains stable after the addition of 3 mL of CH3OH (2 M) in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte, which is prior to Pt/C that a sharp drop appears after the addition of methanol (Fig. 5 a). This result confirms that the Co/NSC catalyst exhibits excellent methanol-tolerance during ORR. The CA and cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were used to investigate the stability of the prepared materials. The CA test shows that the final current density for Co/NSC catalyst is 92.45%, higher than that of commercial Pt/C (84.61%) (Fig. 5b). This result indicates the excellent long-term stability of Co/NSC catalyst toward ORR, which is supported by the result of 10,000 cyclic CV test, where the half-wave potential of Co/NSC catalyst only exhibits a negative shift 15 mV (Fig. 5c), lower than that of commercial Pt/C (58 mV, Fig. 5d). Both CA and CV measurements verify the excellent catalytic stability of the Co/NSC catalyst. This high ORR performance can be ascribed to the excellent conductivity Co/NSC catalyst, as confirmed by the impedance experiment (Fig. S3), the charge transfer resistance (R ct) of Co/NSC is 23.0 Ω, much lower than that of Pt/C (58.9 Ω). The high electrical conductivity Co/NSC benefits the faster charge transfer in the electrochemical process [69]. The practical application of the prepared catalyst is assessed by a homemade Zn-air battery, in which the carbon paper loaded with catalyst samples (Co/NSC or commercial Pt/C, 1 mg cm–2) and zinc plate were assembled as the cathode and anode, respectively. The open circuit voltage (OCV) of Co/NSC catalyst is 1.467 V, which is higher than that of commercial Pt/C (1.427 V) (Fig. 6 a). The power density is calculated from the discharge curve by the formula of P = U × I (where, P represents power density, U represents potential, and I represents current density) and the calculated values are present in Fig. 6b. The maximum power density of the Co/NSC catalyst is 156.2 mW cm-2, which is 1.24-fold higher than that of commercial Pt/C (125.93 mW cm-2). The specific capacity was normalized to the consumptions of the zinc plate that discharge continuously at 20 mA cm-2 until the occurrence of the broken circuit. The calculated specific capacity of the Co/NSC catalyst is 747.9 mAh gZn -1, higher than that of the commercial Pt/C (712.4 mAh gZn -1) (Fig. 6c). After separately discharging for 1.5 h at the current density of 2, 5, 10, 5, 2 mA cm-2, the discharge voltage of the Co/NSC catalyst is still higher than that of commercial Pt/C (Fig. 6d). This result again confirms the excellent stability of the Co/NSC catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, we demonstrated a method for the preparation of Co/NSC. After the aging and pyrolysis, the N and S were successfully doped into the carbon film. More importantly, the Co nanoparticles were coated by the N, S co-doped carbon film, which strengthens the interaction between the Co nanoparticles and carbon film, and facilitates the electron rearrangement of Co/NSC. In addition, the designed Co/NSC catalyst exhibits a large specific surface area, offering a high density of exposed active sites of Co-NX. These advantages give the Co/NSC catalyst a high half-wave potential of 0.860 V, which is comparable to that of commercial Pt/C and higher than that of recently reported non-noble metal catalysts. Furthermore, the Co/NSC catalyst highlights excellent stability and anti-methanol, outperforming the commercial Pt/C. The assembled Zn-air battery, using Co/NSC as the cathode catalyst, demonstrates a high open circuit voltage (1.467 V), large peak power density (156.2 mW cm-2), great specific capacity (747.9 mAh gZn -1), and excellent stability. Therefore, this work provides an approach for the preparation of N, S co-doped materials and the core-shell mental@C materials. The prepared catalyst can be used in the energy storage and conversion devices. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical energy (e.g., fuel cell and metal-air batteries) is featured by large theoretical energy density, high conversion efficiency, safe operation and pollution-free emission. However, the sluggish dynamics of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and high cost of noble metals hinder their widespread commercial applications in electrochemical energy devices. Herein, we present a method for the preparation of the N, S co-doped carbon film wrapped Co nanoparticles (Co/NSC) for ORR by aging and then pyrolyzing the mixture of cobalt salt and 1-(p-Toluenesulfonyl)imidazole. The co-doping of N and S facilitates the electron rearrangement of the carbon film, resulting in a rapid electron transfer. The core-shell structure enhances the interaction between N, S co-doped carbon film and Co nanoparticles. These features endow the Co/NSC catalyst an excellent ORR with a half-wave potential of 0.860 V and limiting current density of 6.2 mA cm-2, besides the superior anti-methanol. The Co/NSC catalyst as the air cathode grants the assembled zinc-air battery high open circuit voltage (1.467 V), large peak power density (156.2 mW cm-2), great specific capacity (747.9 mAh gZn -1), and excellent stability. Thus, the prepared Co/NSC catalyst exhibits a promising application in zinc-air battery. This work provides an approach for the synthesis of the carbon-shell coated non-noble metal catalyst and its subsequent applications in oxygen electrocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: N, S co-doped carbon film wrapped Co nanoparticles for boosting oxygen reduction reaction
